params.text:
• Rely on transparent words & identify
  • Recognise false friends
  • Identify time words & tenses

Reading

Understand a short text 2

Language in Action
Reading: Introduction
Here’s what we’ll go through today:

1. Rely on transparent words and identify: We’ll look at some ways to understand words that look like words in your language.

  2. Recognise false friends: We’ll learn about words that look similar but have different meanings.

  3. Identify time words & tenses: We’ll learn about words that tell us when things happen.
Rely On Transparent Words & Identify: Key Points
Please click on the following information boxes to identify transparent words:
Look for similar words:
Look at the picture:
Guess the word:

• Some English words look like words in your language. They might have a similar meaning.
    Example: Happy is similar to the word in many languages.

• Sometimes, a picture can help you understand the word.
    Example: A picture of a cat next to the word cat can help you learn the word.

• If you don’t know the word, try to guess its meaning. Look at the other words around it to help you.
    Example: If you see the words I like and ice cream you can guess that ice cream is something you like to eat
Look for the same word:

• Sometimes, words are the same in English and your language.
    Example: Stop! is the same in many languages.
Rely On Transparent Words & Identify: Reading and Quiz

Dear Team,

Please be advised of a new company policy regarding name tags. All employees are now required to wear a company-issued name tag while in the office.

Name tags will be available at the front desk. They should be worn visibly at all times during your workday. This policy is being implemented to enhance employee identification.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Best regards,

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is the new company policy?
answers:
employees must wear a name tag. 

All employees must wear a watch. 

All employees must wear a suit.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Where can employees get a name tag?
answers:
At the front desk.

At home.

At the store.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Why has this policy been implemented?
answers:
To enhance employee identification.

To look more professional.

To improve office morale.

params.text: Please read the following text and answer the questions:
Rely On Transparent Words & Identify: Reading and Quiz

Dear Team,

We are excited to announce a change to our office lunch policy. To promote a healthier and more social workplace, we will now have a designated lunch area. This area is on the first floor, near the kitchen.

Please eat your lunch in this area. We hope you enjoy this new space.

Thank you,

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Where is the new lunch area?
answers:
On the first floor.

On the second floor.

Outside.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What should you do with your lunch?
answers:
Eat it in the new lunch area. 

Eat it at your desk.

Share it with others.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Why is there a new lunch area?
answers:
For better health.

For more fun.

For more work.

params.text: Please read the following text and answer the questions:
Recognise False Friends: Key Points
Please click on the information points for useful tips to recognise words:
Read the sentence:
Use a dictionary:
Remember the word pair:
• The other words in the sentence can help you understand the word.
• A dictionary can show you the correct meaning of the word.
• Try to remember the English word and the French word together.
Look at the picture:
• Sometimes a picture can help you understand the word.
Recognise False Friends: Quiz

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What should you do if you don’t understand a word?
answers:
Look at the picture.

Guess the meaning.

Eat a sandwich.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: How can the other words in a sentence help?
answers:
They can help you understand the word.

They can be the same as in French.

They can make you laugh.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What can a dictionary show you?
answers:
The correct meaning of the word.

A picture of the word.

A funny story.

params.text: Please answer the following questions!
Identify Time Words & Tenses: Key Points
Please click on the information points for useful tips to recognise identify time words and tenses:
Look at the verb:
Read the whole sentence:
Practice, practice, practice:

• The verb can tell you about the time.
    Example sentence: I worked yesterday

• Sometimes the whole sentence helps you understand the time.
    Example sentence: Last week, I went to the cinema

• The more you read and listen, the better you will be at understanding time.
    Example: Read books, listen to music, and watch movies in English
Look for special words:

• Some words tell you about time.Examples: now, yesterday, tomorrow.
    Example sentence: I am happy now.
Please watch the following video and answer the questions:

params.text: Identify Time Words & Tenses: Interactive Video
Identify Time Words & Tenses: Reading and Quiz

Many companies do business with other countries. They sell things to other countries and buy things from them, this is called international business.
It helps companies to grow and become bigger. Big companies often work in many different countries.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What do companies do in international business?
answers:
They work with other countries

They work only in one country.

They close their business.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Why is international business important for companies?
answers:
To grow bigger. 

For fun. 

To stay small.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Where do big companies usually work?
answers:
In many countries.

In one city.

In one country.

params.text: Please read the following text and answer the questions:

Startups are new companies. They often have a special culture. People in startups work hard. They like to try new things. They want to make the company successful. Startups are often small, so people do many different jobs.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What kind of companies are startups?
answers:
New companies.

Big companies.

Old companies.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: How do people in startups work?
answers:
They work hard.

They work slowly.

They work at home.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What are startups often like?
answers:
Small.

Big.

Boring.

params.text: Please read the following text and answer the questions:
Identify Time Words & Tenses: Reading and Quiz
Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: What is a "false friend"?
answers:
A word that looks the same but means different things.

A good friend.

A person who is not nice.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: Which word tells you about time?
answers:
Yesterday

Car

Book

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: What can help you understand a new word?
answers:
A picture

A pencil

A phone

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: What do big companies often do?
answers:
Work in many countries.

Stay in one city.

Close their doors.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: How can you learn new English words?
answers:
By watching TV.

By eating food.

By sleeping.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: What kind of company is a startup?
answers:
A new company.

A big company.

An old company.
